awd_titl_txt: Catalyst Project: Technically Speaking-Building Scientific Communication Self-efficacy
awd_abstract_narration:
Catalyst Projects provide support for Historically Black Colleges and Universities (HBCU) to work towards establishing research capacity of faculty to strengthen science, technology, engineering, and mathematics (STEM) undergraduate education and research. It is expected that the award will further the faculty member's research capability, improve research and teaching at the institution, and involve undergraduate students in research experiences. Albany State University intends to integrate science communication into the science (biology and chemistry) academic programs. The proposed curricular enhancements aim to bolster student scientific communication skills, which has the potential to impact their STEM identity and long-term retention in the STEM workforce. 

The purpose of the Technically Speaking: Building Scientific Communication Self-Efficacy Program (TSP) is to offer empirically based research, which may lead to an improvement of undergraduate STEM students’ academic competency in oral communication, as well as their scientific efficacy. Specific objectives include: (1) establishing course-based learning communities, (2) improve oral scientific communication (3) enhance scientific communication self-efficacy and scientific identity and (4) improve critical-thinking skills. Research is intended to lead to higher retention and graduation within STEM fields. The project, over the span of 2 years, will enroll students into two non-residential learning communities: ARC (Appreciating the Rhetoric of Chemistry) which pairs a chemistry class with a public speaking class and Raising the BAR (Biology and Rhetoric) which pairs a biology course with a public speaking course.  The outreach to the K12 community will contribute to the development of scientific literacy among citizens of the community.  The project will improve students’ ability to orally communicate their scientific pursuits to a broad audience through opportunities for reflection, sustained feedback, and mastery experiences. The TSP has the potential to result in improved STEM education and will help to develop a more competitive STEM workforce.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

por.por_cntn:
In early fall 2021, Albany State University (ASU, GA) was awarded a two-year National Science Foundation-funded, Catalyst grant (Award number: 2107301) under the HBCU-UP program titled, “Technically Speaking: Building Scientific Communication Self-Efficacy” (TSP). The project led to an improvement of undergraduate STEM students’ academic competency in the oral communication of their STEM research, as well as their scientific efficacy. The following objectives were met:

1.         The establishment of two course-based learning communities: Appreciating the Rhetoric of Chemistry (ARC) which paired a chemistry class with a public speaking class and Raising the BAR (Biology and Rhetoric) which paired a biology course with a public speaking course.  In their public speaking class, students presented their biology or chemistry laboratory research. Additionally, students engaged in mastery experiences that included presenting their research to the public at the local Boys and Girls Club and at the institution’s Center for Undergraduate Research Conference.

2.         An improvement of oral scientific communication: Students pre-post surveys and informal observations made by the PI and Co-PIs indicated an increase in students’ self-perception, confidence levels, and an ability to effectively communicate their STEM topics to an audience. This was significant from the beginning to the end of the semester— as noted by the project team who conducted their observations at random and debriefed afterward. The PI noted that less time was required to design the speeches at the end of the semester. Furthermore, using student facilitators and a public speech professor, a feedback loop was included in the public speaking class that allowed for the review of speeches which greatly improved their levels of preparation and confidence levels. For the first session, student facilitator #1 observed each student’s speech and provided feedback. Immediately afterward, facilitator #2 would repeat the step. Finally, the professor would provide feedback to each student.

3.         An enhancement of scientific communication self-efficacy and scientific identity: In pre-post surveys, students overwhelmingly noted that they identified as a STEM person.  One of the last speech assignments asked the students to elaborate on their scientific accomplishments and confidence level.  Eighty percent of students noted that their confidence and accomplishments significantly increased.

In addition to the objective, the PI and Co-PIs presented their finding at two national conferences: 2024 American Association of Colleges and Universities (AAC&U) Transforming STEM Higher Education Conference and the Hawaii University International Conference (HUIC) 2024 STEM/STEAM and Education Conference. The PI and Co-PIs submitted their research for publication consideration. It was subsequently published in the Proceedings of the 2024 STEM/STEAM and Education Conference.
